Layer#

class Layer(connection: Connection, neuron: Neuron, connection_kwargs: dict[str, str] | None = None, neuron_kwargs: dict[str, str] | None = None)[source]#

Bases: Module

Container for sequential Connection and Neuron objects.

This is used as the base building block of spiking neural networks in Inferno, and is used for training models.

Parameters:

  • connection (Connection) – connection between the layer inputs and the neurons.

  • neuron (Neuron) – neurons which take their input from the connection and their output is returned.

  • connection_kwargs (dict[str, str] | None, optional) – keyword argument mapping for connection methods. Defaults to None.

  • neuron_kwargs (dict[str, str] | None, optional) – keyword argument mapping for neuron methods. Defaults to None.

Note

The keyword argument mappings are a dictionary, where the key is a kwarg in a Layer method, and the corresponding value is the name for that kwarg which will be passed to the dependent method in in the Connection or Neuron().

When None, all kwargs are passed in. Included classes in Inferno are written to avoid conflicts, but that is not always guaranteed.

Tip

The composed Neuron does not need to be unique to this layer, and some architectures explicitly have multiple connections going to the same group of neurons. The uniqueness of the composed Connection is not enforced, but unexpected behavior may occur if it is not unique.

clear(**kwargs)[source]#

Resets connections and neurons to their resting state.

Keyword arguments are filtered and then passed to Connection.clear() and Neuron.clear().

property connection: Connection#

Connection submodule.

Parameters:

value (Connection) – replacement connection.

Returns:

existing connection.

Return type:

Connection

forward(*inputs, **kwargs)[source]#

Runs a simulation step of the connection and then the neurons.

Keyword arguments are filtered and then passed to Connection.forward() and Neuron.forward(). It is expected that Connection.forward() outputs a single tensor and Neuron.forward() and takes a single positional argument. The output of the former is used for the input of the latter.
